Definition: In this task, you are given a public comment from online platforms. You are expected to classify the comment into two classes: disagree and no-disagree. Classify the comment as disagree if it expresses strong disagreement.

Positive Examples.input:
Comment: A whole boring column to connect Leitch to a white supremacist.

Leah,
Leave political commentary to the pundits , I am sure there is something trendy you can write about.
Positive Examples.explanation: This comment expresses its strong disagreement with the previous comment.

Positive Examples.input: Comment: See, O.L. Of Fatima really did convert the Russians!
Positive Examples.explanation: This comment does not express any sign of disagreement.

Negative Examples.input: Comment: I have no love for the Chiefs, but it was wonderful seeing Brady on his ass.
Negative Examples.explanation: This comment does not show clear agreement or disagreement, and thus should be classified as no-disagree.

Negative Examples.input: Comment: Not a smart President. Sad.
Negative Examples.explanation: This comment shows disagreement with the president.

Comment: The Khadr payout is, above all, the ultimate object lesson in the importance of due process in our legal system and that the "court of public opinion" thankfully doesn't hold sway. If the system messes with your human rights at any point while you're in it, that's big ... big ... big. And that's regardless of whether you're guilty (I think Khadr is) or were a combatant (I think Khadr was).

But, like I said a few days ago, it's also a business decision, for a couple of reasons. 

One, I'd rather have our government pay $10 million now than $20 million ... or more ... later. Our lawyers urged us to settle because they knew the government of the day screwed up royally. 

Two ... I go back to that scene from A Bronx Tale and the wisdom of Chazz Palminteri's Sonny. If a guy you hate owes you 20 bucks, stop chasing him for the money. Let him keep running away and he'll be out of your life, all for the price of 20 bucks.

Khadr's now out of our lives for $10 million. It's worth it.

Comment: Adverse helicopter noise impacts on residential areas on the big island have been a problem for many many years and the Hawaii Helicopter Operators Association does nothing to mitigate their offensive behavior. Comment: You don’t like the amount of money?  

Blame the Harper government.

Before you curse me, read this….

Khadr filed his suit for damages in 2004, asking for a modest amount of damages. Did we seek his repatriation (as every other Western country did), and try to negotiate a settlement to the law suit then? 

No.

Instead, we fought it – big time.  

There were 30 separate court decisions during the 9 Harper years – all (or almost all?) of which we lost.  How much did those losses cost?  I found out the cost of two (2) of them so far, from Hansard: the 2008 and 2010 Supreme Court cases -  slightly over $625,000.  I wonder what the other 28 cost.  

After the 2010 SCC decision confirming that our government had seriously violated his Charter rights, Khadr’s team amended the  damage claim, way up – because they had more evidence and the biggest issue in the case was then proven.  Did we try to negotiate a settlement then?  

No. The Harper government fought him for another 20 decisions.

Comment: La Hopkins should terminate her patently false references to CPI_common as “the best gauge of the economy’s underperformance”. It is now registering a 1.4% inflation rate when most, if not all economic indicators are positive. It was at 2.7%, close to the Bank of Canada’s upper bound, in March 2009, near the trough of the 2008-09 recession. A measure of the economy’s underperformance would be a measure of the potential output gap, a foggy concept at best. In any case, if you swallow the Bank of Canada’s work it found a higher correlation between CPI-trim and the output gap (0.6) than between CPI-common and the output gap (0.5) and with a smaller lag (two quarters as opposed to six quarters).

Comment: For the last 16 months I have had to pay a fixed blended rate because our "dumb meter " cannot track time of  use.They "estimate usage" based on historical data and read the meter every 3 months . I was shocked this past January when I received the largest hydro bill ever , almost double from one year ago.  I called hydro and was told it was based on historical usage , which is BS because they also doubled my historical usage from one year ago. I went out and read my own meter and subtracted the actual consumption from my last reading and wow,were they ever off. After confronting them with the actual meter reading they agreed that something was wrong and told me to "ignore the bill".

So because of that incident I now read my own meter , take a photo of the reading as evidence,and I am pleased to say that we are doing a good job on our energy consumption .

Here is the lesson-read your own meter and compare it to your billing ,as their practices and meter technology cannot be trusted.

Comment: Your 1st sentence made my exact point.
The completion % in a box score after a game has absolutely NO way to discern between an incompletion that was a perfect throw but bounced off a WR's chest, vs 1 where a QB BADLY misses a guy who's wide open. 
And it DEFINITELY can't measure whether a QB's good or bad pass occurred on 1st down in the 1st quarter, or on the last play of a game, down by 2 pts.

By your odd way of thinking, Siemian, w/a career completion % of 60 is a better QB than John Elway, because HIS was only 56.9%; which means that you're missing literally everything.
By the OLD rating, Siemian ranks 24th in the NFL(still bad).
But by ESPN's QBR, where experts give a QB more credit for reading the defense and making a great 10 yd throw at a crucial time, than a crappy 10 yd throw that a WR catches anyway EARLY in the game, he's ranked 26th.
Pro Football Focus ALSO uses experts, & ALSO judges QB's ACTUAL play, has him ranked 32nd. 
And yes, 32nd in a 32 team league IS horrible.

Comment: Mr. Gibson really should get some legal advice before he sticks his neck out and makes a fool of himself.

Section 92(10(a) empowers a province to legislate over various local works and undertakings:

            "(a) Lines of Steam or other Ships, Railways, Roads, Telegraphs, and other Works and Undertakings         connecting the Province with any other or others of the Provinces, or extending beyond the Limits of the Province

Pipelines are not mentioned.      

The federal Parliament  can, however, declare a work to be for the general benefit of Canada or three or more provinces under section 92(10(c):

           "(c) Such Works as, although wholly situate within the Province, are before or after their Execution declared by the Parliament of Canada to be for the general Advantage of Canada or for the Advantage of Three or more of the Provinces.

In the absence of a federal declaration, B.C. is within its rights to lay down condition for the expansion of this pipeline.

Comment: "The 1969 White Paper (officially entitled Statement of the Government of Canada on Indian policy) was a Canadian policy paper proposal made in 1969 by Prime Minister Pierre Trudeau and his Minister of Indian Affairs, Jean Chrétien. The federal government proposed that by eliminating "Indian" as a distinct legal status, the resulting equality among all Canadians would help resolve the problems faced by Aboriginal peoples. The main provision of the White Paper was to eliminate Indian status as a distinct legal status for Aboriginal people, which the federal government envisioned as a step to achieving equality among all Canadians, by regarding Aboriginals as equal citizens like other Canadians."

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1969_White_Paper

Manning sent the materials to Wikileaks after every other avenue had been blocked, following  exactly what the law proscribes by doing so. Her military trial specifically denied her defense the ability to bring up or argue this responsibility and therefore her conviction should be considered an abuse of process.

"The trade of slaves across the Sahara and across the Indian Ocean also has a long history, beginning with the control of sea routes by Muslim Arab and Swahili traders on the Swahili Coast during the ninth century (see Sultanate of Zanzibar). Some historians assert that as many as 17 million people were sold into slavery on the coast of the Indian Ocean, the Middle East, and North Africa, and approximately 5 million African slaves were bought by Muslim slave traders and taken from Africa across the Red Sea, Indian Ocean, and Sahara desert between 1500 and 1900."

Comment: Hate to break it to you, but Canada is not and never has been a democracy.

It is a top-down English colonial system some would call a "pseudocracy", whose main goal was to muzzle settlers who were prone to thinking they had been sold a bill of goods,-- as in the rebellions of the Upper and Lower Canadas in 1837.

The word "democracy" and its cognates appears nowhere in the original Confederation Act of 1867. It appears three times in the so-called Constitution Act of 1982, twice as captions and once in graciously conferring the right to vote,-- a right shared with such egregious regimes as North Korea. The 1982 Act is a sham never ratified by Québec, cosily and paternalistically formulated by Pierre Trudeau and the remaining Premiers over the heads of Canadians.

The only threat to this canard is that Canadians will look covetously at the success of another system, and want to jettison it and the corrupt sinecurists holding them to ransom.

Hence the unease over Donald Trump.

Comment: Yes, nonsense (to me). One studies the evidence in order to decide what's true. If no evidence is provided, it may or may not be true. 'Extraordinary claims require extraordinary evidence.'

A belief is an imagined truth, and therefore nonsense. I don't recall having been encouraged to fantasize what might be true and accept that-- or guess at what might be true-- I was encouraged to prove it.

I do recall, however, learning the Scientific Method for investigating phenomena.  Prove the data; strive to disprove the data, undergo peer review, publish, receive criticism (even ridicule).  And after a decade or more, a nugget of truth may stand at the bottom of a beaker, or scrawled upon a black board.

As a secular parent, I would pass on the affirmations I have received by being a critical thinker, and I would encourage that approach for my children-- question everything.

If something is proven to be true, we are all compelled to accept it.

I have no 'beliefs' to pass on, however.

- Edwin's agent really screwed this up.  Yes, it is possible for both sides to be in the wrong here.  Edwin wound up taking a deal that was inferior to the one the Jays initially offered.  Edwin was looking for 5/$125, and its clear that deal wasn't out there for him.  His agent misread the market, and Edwin had to settle for less guaranteed money.

- The Jays will be worse on opening day in 2017 than they were on opening day in 2016.  They won't be younger, they won't be more athletic, they will have worse players.  I don't think you can argue any of that.

Comment: You clearly do not understand the life cycle of toxoplasma gondii or how people and animals become infected.

Toxoplasma gondii (Tg) can only complete its life cycle in the intestine of a member of the cat family.  Only cats.  The cat then sheds the Tg oocysts (eggs) in its feces by the tens of millions per cat.  Rats and other mammals do not shed oocysts.  Only cats.  The reason the soil, water, or plant material is contaminated with oocysts is because cats are shedding them.  There would not be environmental contamination of oocysts if cats weren't there to shed them.  Recent research indicates that cats can become reinfected and go through add'l oocyst shedding cycles.  The oocysts are very durable and can remain viable in soil or water for 18 months or more.  In dry conditions they can become aerosolized and inhaled.  Oocysts can also be spread by insects or rodents from feces to food sources.

Comment: I think in all fairness that before the Liberals end omnibus bills for good, they should have the opportunity to try one out for their political advantage. They have a lot of ground to make up after the disastrous Harper years, and Conservative complaints are falling on my deaf ears.

Comment: The Swedes have a name for this: döstädning. It means "death cleaning." The idea is to declutter your home before you die so your crap isn't a burden on your heirs who have to deal with it all.
Having spent 20 yrs in the military, moving about every two years or so, I learned the importance of not keeping stuff you don't really need or want. We tend to fill the available space in our living quarters.
Look around you. Think about the last time you used that old exercise equipment or that third TV. And never mind all the rubbish in your junk drawer. Why keep it all?

Comment: I didn't say that one's religious principles can transcend the law. However, the RFRA, which is the law of the land, passed by a bipartisan legislature and signed by a Democratic president, does state that "Government shall not substantially burden a person’s exercise of religion even if the burden results from a rule of general applicability." As a liberal, I think that makes sense, and I'm not really sure it's worth it to force conservative bakers to sell cakes for gay weddings. The principle of religious freedom means a lot to me, as it's one of the hallmarks of the enlightenment and liberal values, and it really pains me to see so many people who call themselves "progressive" appear so willing to hem that in. I can see it for some issues, like housing discrimination, but cakes? As for your other point, obviously a government official must do her job. If she can't, she should resign. The courts ruled as much.

Comment: A few things to note here:

First – weed today is not stronger than it was “back in the day”. That’s a myth and should have been caught by the editor before this garbage column was published. 

Second – the molecules that make up the smell of weed smoke are non-polar. This means they will only dissolve in oil and not water. That is why weed smoke – while you may not like the smell – is not very “sticky”. It goes away after awhile and doesn’t infest your clothes (unless you haven’t washed them in awhile in which case they will have a lot of body oil in them). The molecules that make tobacco smoke smell are polar molecules. This means they will dissolve in water. That is why being around someone who is smoking tobacco can make your clothes smell terrible later on and why tobacco smoke is so “sticky”. 

Third – weed doesn’t remove ambition. At least, it hasn’t removed mine. If anything it allows me to relax and decompress after a long week at work.

Worst. Eddie. Column. Ever.

Comment: Then you and I agree on the point that voter suppression and similar tactics are illegal. However, you go on to say, "so long as they can, legitimately prove they qualify as meeting the requirements of a legal voter." In other words, guilty until proven innocent. This is where you and I disagree. In many cases, it would be easier to prove if a person were NOT legally entitled to vote than to prove that they were. Just as in a criminal case, it is often difficult to prove innocence than to prove guilt. It's often impossible to prove a negative.
When it comes to voting, I believe that the onus of that proof belongs with the election board. If a person commits a crime, that person is innocent until proven guilty and that includes the crime of voter fraud.
For example, how would you prove to any authority who you were? Present a driver's license or similar document? They could say those are forgeries.
It's an affront to our democracy for honest U.S. citizens to be denied the right to vote.

Comment: Two ideas that were helpful for my mother. I got the simplest iPod and headphones and loaded songs from the 30's, 40's and 50's, the years she remembered in her late stage AD. This was not simply entertainment. It would often stimulate her enough that she would eat a meal, rather than not eat at all. And I replaced the chairs in her room (long term care facility) with a small, two-seat sofa. During visits, that let us sit side by side, sharing a little body warmth, holding hands and sometimes doing nothing else. Everyone needs human contact especially when others means of communication are slipping away. This was a simple way to enhance it.
